Panorama¶

The Panorama property holds the panorama created from the point cloud, depending on a property (ColorProperty.ColorProperty, CurvatureProperty.CurvatureProperty, etc.). These are created based on SphericalCoordinates.SphericalCoordinates class).

Panorama Property¶

class PanoramaProperty.PanoramaProperty(sphericalCoordinates, rowIndexes=None, columnIndexes=None, panoramaData=None, intensityData=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A panoramic representation of the point set.

Note

For the Scanstation C10 the measurements’ angular resolution for both elevation and azimuth directions:

  • Low: :math: 0.2^circ
  • Medium: :math: 0.11^circ
  • High: :math: 0.057^circ
  • Highest: :math: 0.028^circ

The panorama will always include a range image and will include intensity image data if available, and other properties arranges as panorama, if available.

Attributes

Points Holds the points dataset
Raster Holds raster dataset
Size The image panorama shape
azimuth_spacing Azimuth angle resolution size
column_indexes The column index of each point
elevation_spacing Elevation angle resolution size

max_elevation Maximal elevation value in data
min_azimuth Minimal azimuth value in data
min_elevation Minimal elevation value in data
panoramaImage The data as panorama image.
panoramaIndex The point indices in a panorama.
path The path of the dataset
rangeImage The range as panorama
row_indexes The row index of each point
sphericalCoordinates Point in spherical coordinates
void_data Value set for void areas

Size¶

The image panorama shape

adaptive_smoothing(phenomena_size, img_to_smooth=None, verbose=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Adaptive smoothing of the panorama image according to the range image.

Note

The function is implemented similar to other smoothing functions (e.g., cv2.GaussianBlur; cv2.Blur), so different kinds of smoothing functions will be applicable by sending (without if). This means that the function will return computed sigma and ksize according to the average - and they will be returned in the variable.

An adaptive smoothing is implemented as a family of convolution kernels characterized by different \(\sigma\) values where:

\[d(\rho )=\frac{D}{\rho \Delta }\]

with \(D\), the object-space size of the window, and \(\Delta\) the angular sampling resolution and \(\rho\) is the measured range.

[Ara13]

Todo

Add optionality for adaptive smoothing for other properties panoramas, where adaptation is according to range information

Parameters:
  • phenomena_size (float) – the minimal size of the phenomena that we don’t want to smooth (:math: D above) default: 0.2 m (and in cases that it is sent 0)
  • img_to_smooth (np.ndarray) – the image that should be smoothed.
  • verbose (bool) – print kmean and sigma mean
Returns:

smoothed image
Return type:

tuple
azimuth_spacing¶

Azimuth angle resolution size

column_indexes¶

The column index of each point

computePanoramaDerivatives_adaptive(order, ksize=0.2, sigma=1.0, img_to_compute='panoramaData', blur_window=(0, 0))[source]¶

Numerical and adaptive computation of central derivatives in x and y directions

Parameters:
  • order – the derivatives order (1 or 2)
  • ksize – world window size (meters). Default: 0.2 m
  • sigma – sigma for gaussian blurring. Default: 1. If sigma=0 no smoothing is carried out
  • img_to_compute – if sent, the derivatives will be computed on this image, according to the range image. Default: ‘panoramaData’

String possibilities:

  • ‘intensity’
  • ‘range’
Parameters:blur_window (tuple) – tuple of window size for blurring
Returns:tuple of the derivatives in the following order: \((d_{\theta}, d_{\phi}, d__{\theta\theta}, d{\phi\phi}, d_{\theta\phi})\)
Return type:tuple
computePanoramaGradient_adaptive(gradientType='L1', ksize=0.2, sigma=1, img_to_compute='panoramaData', blur_window=(0, 0), **kwargs)[source]¶

Compute panorama gradient adaptively and numerically

Parameters:
  • gradientType (str) – ‘L1’ L1 norm of grad(I); ‘L2’ L2-norm of grad(I); ‘LoG’ Laplacian of gaussian
  • ksize (float) – world window size (meters). Default: 0.2 m
  • resolution (float) – kernel resolution
  • sigma (float) – sigma for gaussian blurring. Default: 1. If sigma=0 no smoothing is carried out
  • img_to_compute (str or np.ndarray) – if sent, the derivatives will be computed on this image, according to the range image. Default: ‘panoramaData’
  • blur_window (tuple) – tuple of window size for blurring
Returns:

an image of the gradient magnitude
Return type:

np.array
elevation_spacing¶

Elevation angle resolution size

extract_area(left_top_corner, right_bottom_corner)[source]¶

Create a new panorama according to a bounding box

Parameters:
  • left_top_corner (tuple) – (row, column) of the left top corner of the extracted area
  • right_bottom_corner (tuple) – (row, column) of the right bottom corner of the extracted area
Returns:

a pointsubset according to the bounding box
Return type:

PointSubSet

Get a specific characteristic value of the property

Returns:value for each point
Return type:np.array

Warning

This function needs to be overwritten for each inheriting property. It is empty at the BaseProperty

intensityImage¶

The intensity data as panorama image. If no data stored, it will return None.

The data as panorama image. If no data stored, the range image is returned

The point indices in a panorama. If no point exist the value is NaN

Panorama Factory¶

class PanoramaFactory.PanoramaFactory[source]¶

Creates a panoramic view from point set based on a certain property (e.g. range, intesity, etc.) The panoramic view is stored as a PanoramaProperty object

Methods

CreatePanorama(points[, azimuthSpacing, …]) Create a PanoramaProperty object from a point set.
_PanoramaFactory__computePanoramaIndices(…) Find the boundaries and the indices of the panorama
_PanoramaFactory__compute_void_as_mean(ranges) Sets the void value as the mean value of the ranges
classmethod CreatePanorama(points, azimuthSpacing=0.057, elevationSpacing=0.057, property_array=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a PanoramaProperty object from a point set.

Parameters:
  • points (PointSet or BaseProperty) – The point set to create the panorama from can be either a PointSet, PointSubSet or BaseProperty-derived objects
  • azimuthSpacing (float) – The spacing between two points of the point set in the azimuth direction (scan property)
  • elevationSpacing (float) – The spacing between two points of the point set in the elevation direction
  • property_array (numpy.array) – if the values of the property to present cannot be retrieved by a simple getValues()
  • voidData (float) – the value for NoData. Default: 250 (meters)
Returns:

panorama_property
Return type:

PanoramaProperty
